This is taking too long. I think they have found something to narrowly focus on that will let them sent it back with comments. Starting to drop the slider. In Minnesota Voters Alliance v. Mansky, the Supreme Court reversed the Eighth Circuit, ruling that Minnesota statute prohibiting clothing with political speech at polling places violated the First Amendment. In this case, the Minnesota Voters Alliance and several other groups and individuals, including the Minnesota Northstar Tea Party Patriots and the Election Integrity Watch (collectively referred to by the court as Minnesota Voters Alliance or MVA), filed suit against the Minnesota Secretary of State and other elections officials in Minnesota. The plaintiffs claimed that Minnesota Statute § 211B.11 violated their rights under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. They alleged that the statute chilled their free speech rights because it prohibited them from wearing apparel with Tea Party logos to their polling places. On a vote of 7 - 2, the Supreme Court reversed the Eighth Circuit, ruling that the Minnesota statute violated the First Amendment. Chief Justice John Roberts authored the majority opinion, joined by Justices Anthony Kennedy, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, Elena Kagan, and Neil Gorsuch. Roberts ruled, "Minnesota’s ban on wearing any 'political badge, political button, or other political insignia' plainly restricts a form of expression within the protection of the First Amendment." However, he continued, because the ban applied only to polling places, the statute "implicates our 'forum based’ approach for assessing restrictions that the government seeks to place on the use of its property.” He wrote that polling places are nonpublic forums in which the government has some freedom to restrict free speech rights. Therefore, as an initial matter, "in light of the special purpose of the polling place itself, Minnesota may choose to prohibit certain apparel there because of the message it conveys, so that voters may focus on the important decisions immediately at hand." But the prohibition, he concluded, must be clearer than the statute in this case in order to pass First Amendment muster: "If a State wishes to set its polling places apart as areas free of partisan discord, it must employ a more discernible approach than the one Minnesota has offered here." Justice Sonia Sotomayor dissented from the majority's judgment, joined by Justice Stephen Breyer. Sotomayor argued that, because the case concerned a state law, the Supreme Court should have allowed Minnesota state courts to rule on the constitutionality of the statute first. She wrote, "Especially where there are undisputed many constitutional applications of a state law that further weighty state interests, the Court should be wary of invalidating a law without giving the State’s highest court an opportunity to pass upon it."  She concluded, "Because the Court declines to take the obvious step of certification in this case, I respectfully dissent."

a court can and should strike a statute down in its entirety in response to a successful
constitutional challenge. The Supreme Court’s position on this issue can be readily
summarized in one word: rarely. (663)

Individual 1A rights run smack dab into States rights to conduct their elections. A Sticky Wicket indeed.  This was a case about the scope of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution in the context of polling places.[1] Generally, the right to free speech ensures the right to express political beliefs, including by wearing clothing with political slogans, badges, or insignia. However, under earlier United States Supreme Court cases, states may prohibit some measure of political expression inside polling places when voting is underway. The issue in this case how far a state can constitutionally go in prohibiting political expression in polling places. Specifically, the issue is whether a state can ban not only outright political endorsements of a candidate but also political expression that does not make reference to a candidate or issue on the ballot that day. The Minnesota statute at issue is Statute § 211B.11. Minnesota Statute § 211B.11 "prohibits wearing a 'political badge, political button, or other political insignia . . . at or about the polling place on primary or election day.”[1][2] The statute "broadly prohibits any material 'designed to influence and impact voting,' or 'promoting a group with recognizable political views,' even when the apparel makes no reference to any issue or candidate on the ballot."[3] Under the statute, a person who wore political apparel to a polling place was still allowed to vote. However, if the person refused to cover or remove the item, an election judge was to "record the person's name and address for potential misdemeanor prosecution."[1] The issue is whether the prohibition of all political apparel violates the right to free speech under the First Amendment.[1]
https://ballotpedia.org/Minnesota_Voters_Alliance_v._Mansky
I except something more narrow in scope than declaring the ban as facially unconstitutional.

I found this tough.  Other narrower statutes were mentioned as less restrictive alternatives that do not impair a state’s interest.  The Court does not permit banners or buttons in its own plaza.  Counsel for the state had the uncomfortable position in oral arguments of claiming that wearing a t-shirt with some parts of the Bill of Rights would violate the law while other parts would not.  There is evidence in the record that some of the litigants intended to wear slogans to intimidate others and prevent them from voting.  I think it could go either way if the Court were forced to decide.  But the Court is not forced to decide and might punt.  Punting would avoid affirming or overturning precedent while giving justices an opportunity to lay out a road map for a future challenge in an opinion, then select a future case with better facts.
I assigned probabilities to each judge and computed the aggregate probability.

However, If those facts were not argued at trial, then the argument may not nessesarily, be used at Appeal or before SCOTUS, although it appears this was the State's argument. Thus 95% yes, inclusive of a no decision.

This law would cause a loophole for people and politicians to intimidate voters, and therefore represents more harm to society than good.

I believe this statute will not be ruled facially unconstitutional. That said, it seems the justices are skeptical of the application to displays that are not explicitly political (e.g., supporting gun rights vs. supporting a specific referendum, by name, that expands gun rights). The statute language is somewhat vague but to throw it out completely would put into question precedent regarding electioneering at polling places.

Wearing all white is non-political according to the statute, but what about wearing all white robe with a white hoodie? Maybe you like to wear white, but to others, you could be wearing the KKK lynching uniform. How about the American flag? It is non-political in the room, but it is political one way or another when wear as clothing.

For me this question turns on - Supreme Court ruling that the state's ban on political apparel at polling places is as-applied unconstitutional will not count. IMO this case has not developed details sufficient to rule either way. I think this gets kicked back to 8th Circuit.

Interesting question. 
Transcripts of the questioning are available.  As another participant noted, questions did not seem to follow usual left /right splits.  People have an explicit right to free speech, unless there is a compelling public interest, and that compelling public interest is framed as narrowly as possible. States have a explicit right to set voting standards.  They have a compelling interest in maintaining a voting site free of intimidation.  Minnesota's ban is more explicit that almost all states; and as a general rule elections run fine in other states.  Arguing in favor of facial overturn
1.  The statute is subjective.  
2.  It is impossible to state what would and would not be banned.   First Amendment T-shirts would not be; 2nd Amendment would be.    What about #I Miss Bill.   #Dreamer  #Chamber of commerce. 
3.  As a subjective matter it violates 14-17 ammendments designed to safe guard  equal rights to vote.
4.  There is additionally the open question - why should polling places be decorous?  Why should the end of the process not be a fracas?
5.  personally, I question the voting booth as a nonpublic forum.  Seem like its the definition of public, to me.  Examining the justices Kegan seems persuadable to strike
Breyer also. 
Gorsuch and Roberts could go either way. Finally there is the question of agency.  Four Justices felt strongly enough about this case - might be the strangest fact of all.  The issues here are relatively minor - except 4 judges thought not. Finally - this case might be a trial balloon to see how the Justices will rule.   There to are a lot of voter's rights questions incoming on the ballot, from gerrymandering,  to voter ID, to voter challenge.   I think this case was accepted to read the tea leaves.  As for facial - there is no other basis to overturn, its a facial challenge.   The as applied elements were excluded from the appeal. TLDR: 75% over turned.

"A person may not provide political badges, political buttons, or other political insignia to be worn at or about the polling place on the day of a primary or election." This sentence is in the context of a law about solicitation.  This law has been in place for over a hundred years. Our legal system employs juries of peers putting life and death questions in regular people's hands. Surely, most election volunteers can interpret whether political apparel or flashing lights worn on the head are solicitous or not. In fact, they have been doing it in Minnesota for over 100 years since the law was enacted and this is the first challenge. However the facts in this case highlight that banning everything goes too far. My guess is that SCOTUS will say a tea party logo, moveon.org, or a rainbow logo for example should not be considered political apparel in this case using the "as applied" test but not strike down the law in its entirety.

Polling places already ban political signs within 50 or 100 feet, depending on your local ordinance.  Also they require you to include who paid for the sign to be printed somewhere on the sign.  So I think as an extension of this, local municipalities can set their own polling place rules on the clothing as well.  A stress free voting environment is important.
Voters are allowed to discuss (verbally) their choices at polling places - the 1st amendement allows expression
Going high due because I assume the conservatives will vote that the Minnesota law and so will Kennedy due to his strong believe in first amendment procedures.
The 1st Amendment guarantees freedom of political expression, but States control their voting procedures

On first glance it appears that the Minnesota ban makes complete sense. But review of the Justice's questions demonstrates why, on its face, this law may be potentially unenforceable.  Firstly, it requires election officers make judgments regarding the political nature of free speech. But if it is ok to wear a shirt with the text of the 1st amendment, why would it NOT be ok to wear one with the text of the 2nd amendment?  Secondly, the issue of political speech becomes relative. The State suggested that political apparel could be potentially acceptable if it did not address the bill up for vote. If this was true, then a "White Power" button would be potentially allowable if the bill were about women's rights, but not if it was about voter ID (or another potentially racially-tinged subject). Thirdly, what is considered political speech may vary over time. The Second Amendment had been relatively insignificant for nearly 200 years until it rose to prominence in 1967 with Bobby Seale and the Black Panthers. If cases were to be challenged by high courts - possibly years or decades later - which standard would courts use regarding what constituted political speech? Interestingly, Justices do not appear to taking sides solely based on political leanings. For instance, Kagan may lean towards overturning the law because she views polls as the culmination of a "rowdy political process." Ginsburg spent a considerable amount of time exploring the limits of the current law, which at times, illustrated how difficult it was to establish any consistent criteria. On the other hand, Sotomayor argued that a "Please ID Me" button could constitute voter intimidation and should be outlawed, suggesting support of the law. We can see similar splits among the traditionally Conservative justices, too. I count 2 justices who support the current law (Breyer, Sotomayor), 5 against (Alito, Garsuch, Kagan, Ginsberg and likely Thomas), and 2 unclear (Roberts, Kennedy). https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument.../16-1435_f2ag.pdf

A facial attack is typically described as one where “no application of the statute would be constitutional.” In contrast, courts define an "as applied" challenge as one “under which the plaintiff argues that a statute, even though generally constitutional, operates unconstitutionally as to him or her because of the
plaintiff’s particular circumstances.”
__________________
Comment: I think it natural for SCOTUS to go with the particular circumstances. In this case, that could translate into declaring Minnesota's ban on political apparel at polling places "as-applied" unconstitutional which does not count for the purposes of this question. I don't see a total rejection of the statute which is what "facially" unconstitutional means.
